DataElement.preferredName: Swollen Gland Neck Gland Edema Patient Self-Report Personal Medical History Yes or No Response
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The region that connects the head to the rest of the body. An organ that makes one or more substances, such as hormones, digestive juices, sweat, tears, saliva, or milk. Endocrine glands release the substances directly into the bloodstream. Exocrine glands release the substances into a duct or opening to the inside or outside of the body. Pathological transudate within one or more tissues. Subjective reports made by the patient. An account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced. A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The region that connects the head to the rest of the body. An organ that makes one or more substances, such as hormones, digestive juices, sweat, tears, saliva, or milk. Endocrine glands release the substances directly into the bloodstream. Exocrine glands release the substances into a duct or opening to the inside or outside of the body. Pathological transudate within one or more tissues. Subjective reports made by the patient. An account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: An enlarged lymph node. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.
The region that connects the head to the rest of the body.
An organ that produces and secretes hormones (e.g. endocrine gland), saliva or sweat (e.g. exocrine gland).
Accumulation of an excessive amount of fluid in cells or intercellular tissues.

Property.preferredDefinition: Subjective reports made by the patient:an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: Subjective reports made by a patient.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
